Posted: December 20, 2014
												In The Novelist, you play as a ghost in a house where the Kaplan family has come for a summer vacation. The husband is the titular novelist, the wife is attempting to get back into painting and their young son  has a slight learning disability . Both the child and wife wish to have more family time (amongst other things), whereas the dad is under pressure to complete his current novel in an attempt to meet deadlines. There are also many other events that happen (all narrated via text or background image+text) but I won't go into those to avoid spoilers.The basic gameplay is fairly simple: Teleporting from one active lamp to another (stealth) in your field of view. This is disabled is the difficulty mode called Story. You are suggested to be stealthy so that you have increased story options. Going into people's memories to encounter small "clues" regarding what the character wants. Investigate different objects in the household such as reading notes, diary entries and seeing drawings made by the little boy. Making choices regarding whose desired outcome should play out (the husband's, wife's or child's). There is also an additional option for compromise on one of these outcomes (I think this is not available if you are seen by the family member, but I'm not too sure because I was never detected). The compromise is not always a positive thing, so it feels like a different option not just a second desirable outcome that makes one more family member happy. At night--when everybody is asleep--you can explore the house for clues related to it's past. This is always in the form of diaries or notes that glow.What I liked: The story choices have some genuine emotional impact, at least for me. You may read some of the other reviews which do not agree with mne on this front. The gameplay is simplistic without making small mistakes like too many collectibles, over-dramatic scenes, frustrating/inconsistent stealth mechanics. Some of the other reviewers had issues with bugs but I didn't have any issues (I have completed the game once). The voice acting is very good, and most (if not all) the notes and diary entries are narrated if you enable that option. The Story mode difficulty option is a good choice if you want to introduce the game to a non-gamer.What I misliked: The characters do not have any real in-game chatter/conversations. This was a real bummer but I can understand why this decision was made; if you are in another room, you cannot see the body language of the characters as they talk.  The short story arcs of the history of the house do not really tie in to the main story and are way too short to evoke a genuine response. While the shortness is explained in the context of the story (the house has cheap rent and few takers because of its past tenants' short stays), I think that the brevity robs the stories of genuine emotional impact. The gameplay gets repititive after the 2-hour mark or so. Thankfully the game doesn't overstay its welcome by much.Other notes:The "About This Game" says that: The decisions you make will define the Kaplans’ lives, but they may also tell you something about yourself. While ymmv, I think this was true in my case. There is no one solution makes everybody happy (in a family) and this comes out beautifully in the game. I think at the end of the game, you should have been shown a tree showing the branching decisions you've made and the results of each so that you can look at the ending in a clearer context.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Over the course of three "months", I had to deal with the imaginary hardships of a virtual family of three, struggling to pull together all the fictional unraveling threads of their simulated lives.A failing couple, a writer trying to keep up with his responsibilities, a mother trying to take her own place in the art world with her talents, a child with a reading disability who needs support, and an endless onslaught of stuff getting in the way.Ultimately, nothing you do will turn out quite the way you want. As with Life, you do the best you can.So, Dan finished his book to critical acclaim and retired after a distinguished career.He and his wife, Linda, became closer, bouncing back from the precipice of divorce, instead growing old together in love.At the cost of Linda's hopes for her paintings... and of Tommy's success in life, growing up to be a talentless nobody.It may be the headache and fever from the flu I'm dealing with as I write this, or my emotional exhaustion from my own problems in life, but I cried.I'm still crying. I ask myself what I could have done differently. Did I spend too much time on the book? Should I have let Tommy stay at his school? Perhaps avoid moving so as to let Linda work for her art-based charity group? I ruined the poor kid's life, and it shocks me even though he's just a few pixels in a game.But perhaps I'm crying because I know I could play again and make different choices for Dan, Linda, and Tommy.Perhaps I'm crying because we don't get that chance ourselves.Play this game once.  Only once. It's not fair to get do-overs.I'm sorry, Tommy.

												  The game's minimalist art stole my heart from the moment I saw it. Not only is it easy on the computer- its simply wonderous on your eyes. I honestly don't want to replay the game with different choices- not because it was bad but because it would ruin my immersion.    The game is overall beautiful, memorable, and fun. Posted: January 1, 2015
												The Novelist really does provide a wonderful experience that takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions as you try and meet the needs of two struggling parents and their child. You play as a ghost in their summer house, being able to possess lights in order to get around. You are able to walk around the house (instead of possessing lights), but if you're playing on Stealth mode (which I recommend, because it's not that hard and hence adds a bit more to the experience) and are spotted, this will have negative consequences on the lives you are attempting to save.The main idea of the game is this: you search the house for clues as to what each character's dilemma is. Once you have found these clues, you are then able to search through their memories and try and figure out a solution. Then you choose your solution, which is always a difficult choice given the ramifications. Following this, whilst the family is sleeping, you are able to search the house for information about the history of the house and discover what *you* are. Given that you did not spook any characters whilst looking for information, you are given the ability to make a compromise on someone else's dilemma, making them less disappointed, but there is always someone who will be disappointed.At first, I thought this concept would get boring and repetetive, and after the first month (there are three in total), I thought this was becoming the truth. However, I became intrigued with each character and their story, desiring to make each the most satisfied they could get. Doing this, though, is what is hard. It reminded me of decision-making seen in Telltale's games, where you would feel proud of your decision at first, but no matter what decision it was, you then felt sad and like you really messed up. I don't want to spoil the game, as it is very heavily story-driven, but I will say it again: it was an emotional rollercoaster, but one that I enjoyed all the way through.For the $15 pricetag, I would say waiting for a sale would be a good idea, at least 50% off. It's not that it's a bad game, because I clearly pointed out that it was an enjoyable experience, it's just short. Not TOO short, because I finished it satisfied, but not long enough to justify the price. The aesthetic, sound, controls, and performance had no issues with me, too, so I'd say that anyone who likes a story-driven game (e.g. Telltale games, Brothers) will thoroughly enjoy this little experience.Enjoy :)

Posted: December 8, 2015
												I really liked this one, quite the nice little experience.This is a 'game' as a support to tell a story or rather your version of a story, as your choices will affect the outcome. You're basically a ghost in a house where a family moves in for the summer, and you can 'strongly suggest' what path should be chosen by whispering to the people in their sleep. Each day you can only satisfy one desire, and optionally try to find a midway solution for one other person, leaving the last one frustrated.The writing is all too realistic in representing the fight to try to balance a carreer and a family, dreams and immediate needs, aspirations and desires. You are facing writer's block on a deadline. Your son wants attention and needs support no to fall behind in school and have enough self esteem not to get bullied all the time. Your wife is looking for an outlet for her artistic ambitions as well. So little time...Mechanically you listen to them, see their memories, find enough elements to be able to make an impact on their decisions while they sleep. There's not so much "gameplay" in here except basic exploration of the same little house each day, unless you enable the mode where they can see you and you have to keep hidden behind them or in the lamps. I have not tried it but that sounded really annoying so I stayed in purely story mode when you're totally invisible to the humans around.This game can be haunting, especially if you're an adult with kids. Playing at work during lunch I needed a couple of minutes to get my thought process out of the Kaplan's life back into my own.Pricing might be a bit high, but this is steam.. just wait..

Posted: December 3, 2015
												A man takes his wife & young son to a secluded vacation home so that he can focus on writing his next great novel; little do they know that the house is also home to an unknown supernatural force that can worm its way into the father's mind. No, it's not The Shining, it's The Novelist. In it you play a spirit (or something?? it's not actually specified) haunting a house on a cliff. Your goal is to influence the choices of the father/husband character, Dan, by learning as much as you can about him & his family through written & drawn clues scattered around the house as well as by entering each character's memories. Each chapter presents a situation to which there are three solutions: one that most benefits the dad, one the mom, & one the kid. You can also make a secondary "compromise" choice that will at least partially satisfy one of the other characters if not totally please them.If "Stealth" mode is enabled you have the potential of being spotted by the family while you gather clues during the day, which causes you to lose certain opportunities. You can become invisible & move from one place to the next without being seen by possessing the home's light fixtures, but you can't gather clues when you're in a lamp, so you also have the ability to make a light flicker to distract the family away from where you want to go. There is an alternate "Story" mode where you are invisible no matter where you are. In both modes there are some situations where characters will close doors on you (usually if they're mad about being neglected); you can't open or pass through the doors but the family usually opens them again soon enough. There's a subplot that involves gathering clues about the house's past, but that is not mutable based on the player's choices so it feels more like filler material.The gameplay is fairly straightforward, if a little tedious at times. Think "Gone Home" in a scaled-down form. The graphics are quite lovely, especially the vistas visible through the windows. Several people have singled out the voice acting as exceptional but I didn't find anything remarkable about it. The plot is... okay. I didn't care much for any of the characters, but I still wanted to make good choices for them. There are multiple happy endings & sad endings possible, although not very many, & none too exciting (certainly nothing close to The Shining in that respect!).Overall though this was a nice game to spend a bit of time on; it's pretty relaxing & there's definitely not anything high stress about it. I enjoyed playing through making choices "organically" the first time & then running through it quicker in subsequent replays to get different outcomes. I would definitely recommend doing "Stealth" mode for your first playthrough to get the most out of the experience; enable "Story" for replays so you can move from choice to choice & clue to clue much quicker & don't have to deal with spending time on repeated material. It goes quickly enough when you do that.Even though it would seem there's a lot of responsibility on your shoulders, spending time in this game's world really is soothing, & having different options & routes to take is fun. I like that it's an indie game too. I am happy with my purchase -- but, after all, I bought it on sale, which I would recommend.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												In The Novelist, you play a meddling ghost that seemingly cares about the family renting your summer home, but actually doesn't give a darn what they want, leaving you to invade their minds and choose their life paths for them.Skulking around from room to room, you discover clues to what Dan (a struggling author), Linda (an once and possibly future painter), and Tommy (lonely child) want to do that week. You then can choose whose desire is most important and go that route. Afterward, still images show the fallout of your 'wisdom.'At nighttime, you can seek clues granting additional insight to the house and your role, and you can creepily hover over the sleeping family and listen to their dream thoughts.This game offers two modes, but I don't know what the developer was thinking. This isn't Splinter Cell -- skip the stealth mode, and focus on the story. After all, what's the fun in ruining-- I mean, guiding lives if your ghostly powers can be stripped from you by being spotted?-----Time to put on my serious pants. I think the premise of The Novelist is brilliant, and there are some powerful moments, but the choices often ring artificial. There were a handful of times that all three members could have compromised, but -- as per the game's rules -- only two of three could be chosen. Also, there were moments where it seemed like there would be positive gains for one or more family members, only for negative ramifications to be thrown in your face because the game's writer didn't think things through.Finally, the endings -- especially Tommy's -- seemed at odds with his own personality, let alone some of the story paths.And that whole stealth mode nonsense...Basically, The Novelist is interesting and worth a playthrough, but I can't really call it good. Nonetheless, I'd at least recommend it if you can nab it for a deep discount. On September 8, 2015, it was $2.24 and I think adventure and narrative fans would absolutely get their money's worth.

Posted: April 18, 2015
												This is a game that I am going to give a very soft recommendation for, because while this game has plenty of faults, I still enjoyed playing through it and I think others would too.At it's core, The Novelist is a game about interpersonal conflict and the moral and ethical struggles that comes with trying to balance the wants and needs of individuals in a family. Each chapter in the game presents the player with three desires, one for each member of the family, and you are asked to make a decision based on these desires. I personally enjoyed exploring the house to find all the clues to each family member and I also enjoyed going through their memories to learn more about the situation as well.However there are several problems I have with The Novelist, the chief one being that the story in and of itself isn't that interesting. It's a typical story, Dad wants to work on his novel, Mom wants to save the marriage and get back into a profession she had to give up when the kid arrived, and the kid wants to play with Dad and is struggling in school and is bullied. We've all seen stories that use these elements elsewhere, and they used them a lot better there. Another issue I had was that the individual chapters didn't seem to be all that connected. Each chapter felt more like variations of the same 3 or 4 issues and the decisions made in the previous chapter seemed to have little influence in other chapters.

Posted: June 7, 2015
												The Novelist is a game that wears the title "art game" proudly. The game is short, and can be beaten in about 2 hours, though you're intended to replay through the game if you don't get the best ending (which I got my first try). It's an interesting concept for a game. You play as a ghost that inhabits a summer beach house, as you watch the lives of a novelist and his family unfold over the course of the summer. Your job is to sneak unseen through the house and find various clues about what each family member wants to do for the chapter. You can only pick one of the three options, though at night if you succesfully remained unseen through the day time, you're allowed to pick a compromise option for another member as well. While the game does succesfully avoid the label of walking simulator, the truth is the game play really isn't all that fun. It's insanely easy to remain undeteced through every chapter, making the stealth elements not really matter all that much, and in fact you can even turn off detection in the options menu without any sort of penalty as far as I can tell. Despite controversies surrounding Gone Home, that game at least had a sense of exploration which added a little bit to the game play. Here, there's really nothing. The house is a small two story house with nothing really to explore, or find. The games biggest down fall is that you don't really don't end up caring about the characters. There's nothing incredibly interesting about them, and most of the game consists of them complaining about their lives, or another member of the family. Since you can only choose up to 2 of the 3 options given to you on any given night, this means one is always going to be dissapointed. The only real strategy is just to get on a rotation of selecting each family members option every 3 days, so you can somewhat please everyone. There's no big complicated moral questions that you have to weigh before selecting one such as games by Tell Tale. Here the decisions are rather inane, such as, " should the dad play a board game with his son, or should he spend the night writing a bit of his novel?" If this sounds exciting to you I recommend picking the game up when it's on sale. If you like art games, there are better ones out there than this.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game clocks in at just shy of 2 hours. Most of that time is spent crawling all over the same map, over and over again, searching for "clues" while trying not to get detected by the humans. In nine chapters, you will search one single confined map as many as 36 times for roughly 135 clues - and that's the entire game. You find 135 bits of trash and make nine decisions, choosing each time from six possible alternatives. That is the entire "game;" much like To The Moon, this is a visual novel, not anything a normal person would describe as a game. Frankly, I don't see why this has gotten such accolades.The execution is plodding to say the least; when I said most of your time will be spent "crawling" over the map, I wasn't kidding - the player's movement speed is agonizingly slow; learning to blink most effectively from one light fixture to the next is necessary just to pick up the pace a little.As one tabletop gamer's wife once observed, "it's twenty minutes of fun packed into four hours."

Posted: April 30, 2014
												The Novelist is an original and refreshing idea in storytelling slightly imperfectly executed, but still well worth playing. Coming out of the gate, it's an exhilarating storytelling experience that really gets you engage in the game. The chief issue is that the further you play, the more repetetive and almost rote the gameplay becomes. Add to that some fairly contrived-seeming conflicts of choice, and it falls a little short of the mark that it sets at its outset. However, that mark is so high that what you get instead is still a really worthwhile experience. Part of me wants to replay the game and see what different choices result in, but there's no way to do that quickly, so I'll have to wait until there's more time. I won't be surprised if I do some day return to it, though. If you have any interest at all in unique gameplay and game-based storytelling on a personal level (dealing with ordinary people's lives rather than having to guide the Chosen One to defeat the Emperor of All Evil), then you owe it to yourself to play this game.

Posted: April 22, 2014
												Following the successes of games like Gone Home and Actual Sunlight, The Novelist is another one of those games that will make traditional gamers question whether or not it actually is a game. A huge fan of exploratory/narrative games, however, I did enjoy my 3-4 play-throughs of the game. It doesn't capture the voyeuristic feel quite as fully as Gone Home and doesn't have a story quite as deeply touching as Actual Sunlight; rather, The Novelist falls somewhere between the two as a somewhat memorable, very relatable, and surprisingly touching experience as a voyeur into regular family life. It's a decent game, and although it certainly isn't mind-blowing, it has enough to be worth a play or two.You play as a spectre living in a house that the Kaplan family decides to move into for a summer. Essentially, you "ghost" around the house, reading minds and notes, and help the father (the Novelist) make decisions regarding his family. There really isn't much in the way of gameplay (other than a half-hearted and arguably useless stealth option), so the game could be seen as somewhat of a modern Choose-Your-Own-Adventure novel. Where the game shines is how sincerely and authentically the writing in the game reads: in fact, by the end of a playthrough, you really do care about what happens to the relationship between the mother and the father. It's because of this emotional investment that I found myself playing the game through several times, wanting to find out what would happen to the mother if I did this, or that.Of course, while The Novelist did manage to get me emotionally invested (which, admittedly, is not a difficult task), it does fall short on a few too many things to be considered a memorable or truly laudable game. Off the top of my head, the game failed terribly at getting the audience to care about the child, the "stealth" mechanic was almost laughable and mostly obstructive, and several playthroughs of the game would reveal the endings to be somewhat shallow. Most importantly however, where the game could have been fantastic in its realism, it ended up backing itself into a corner by trying a little too hard. The problems Dan Kaplan faces that summer are very real, but by stressing that "the decisions Dan made that summer would come to define his life" (or something similar), The Novelist almost invites cynicism and throws away any chance it could have had at feeling truly authentic.All in all, The Novelist is a decently good game for what it tries to be. Although nobody is likely to remember it a few years from now, it's a promising first foray into narrative indie game development for Kent Hudson.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												(Originally posted January 13 2014)Just finished playing The Novelist, a thought–provoking adventure game about balancing the competing demands of family life. While the premise of all life–affecting decisions that affect the family being made by the titular male character is a bit offensive to modern sensibilities, given the game's setting in a era of manual typewriters and hand–written letters, it's forgivable, I suppose. The game is structured in a way that makes me suspect that there is no truly "good" ending—I think that someone (one of the game's three characters) will always be left with the short end of the stick, and while that may be a bit contrived, it achieves its intended purpose.I would certainly recommend this game, even to so–called "non gamers"—it's more about observation, experience, and choice, then about gameplay mechanics.

												You are an haunt in a house occupied for the summer by a dysfunctional family - a depressive, alcohol-prone father, a mother who gave up her painting career for family and a son that utterly ignores her, fixated as he it on the fatherly figure whose attention he so much craves that his happiness entirely depends on him.What the game does brilliantly is to remind us, the players, of the tragedy of familiar life, in which the parent's goals could be fulfilled, or at least compromised, if not for the children throwing numerous wrenches in the works. The message is apparently clear: if you want to fulfill your dreams, your descendents won't be heppy, and if you make them happy, you will have failed at your path, ensuring they will fail at theirs when their time as parents come in an eternal cycle of self-denial. Or not :) What remains is that you, the player/presence, whose actions touch so many, seen from time to time creeping right behind someone loved, whose presence is felt thoughout history and with the power to change the minds of the occupiers, you will still be alone and hiding, never really living a story of your own - not until you get out of the house.

Unfortunately, the actual game is terrible due to being the poorly told story of a horrible clan of boring idiots. The people in the house arbitrarily fixate on doing particular things, and then cannot be happy unless everyone else is forced to do that and only that. They'll decide to go camping, for example, and then they will talk of nothing else until ti's been decided. Posted: May 4, 2015
												Uneventful and slow.The gameplay is extremely repetitive. This would be acceptable if the story could hold its own but the characters are bland and the consequences for the player's actions are unfulfilling.  It is essentially a soap-opera played by 3 one-dimensional characters in a single house. Every cliche "issue" that could be experience by a white, middle-class, suburban nuclear family is covered in the duration of the game. It falls down to the player to decide which member of the unlikable trio deserves some kind of help in their endeavours. Each character has something they want to do or want someone else to do. As the player, it is your duty to scour the house for glowy things to press space on and then read whatever clue it holds within. All the clues are a simple rewording of the same message; Dad wants to work on his book so he can provide for his family, Mum wants to be more independant, Kid wants to build a sandcastle or some other meaningless drivel. Once you've found all the clues you can make you decision and find out the consequences (The results of your hard work are usually more whining on the family's part) and do the same thing all over again, except with different glowy clues in different places. This process continues on and on, with little to no character development or indication of story progression, it's just more problems popping up like moles in a whack-a-mole.If you even manage to reach the end, it's highly unlikely that you'll want to go in for round two. In my advice: don't buy this.

												In this title the player is a ghost who walks around at a snails pace or possesses light fixtures to do nothing. You are haunting the cabin of the blandest family possible. There is hardly any characterization or interaction in this story driven game. Your objective is to fufill the desires of one single person either the writer, the mother or the child. Once there desire is fufilled, it is revealed that the lives of the other two family members will take a negative turn; though it doesn't really matter to the player because of how generic each character is. Everyone is devoid of any personality whatsoever. The writer just mopes around never really writing a book the whole time he just fiddles around with an outline that isn't even finished. The child only scribbles crayon drawings of his father with himself either to the left or to the right of his father.On the subject of interaction, there really is not any between the player and the world or for that fact the non playable characters and each other. Every character avoids everyone in the immediate area to the point that they have developed this anti social habit of leaving notes all over the cabin to communicate with eachother.Gameplay consists of reading enough notes so you can use your ghost powers to read a persons mind so you can find a physical object. Once you find that object you finish the quest by entering a characters bedroom at night and whispering boring suggestions into there ears to influence them into living life in a predetermined way.Graphics are horrible. They remind me of this unfinished free game called "Facade" which is a much better game in every regard to "the novelist" and pretty much is the exact same type of game. The only difference is that Facade actually lets you interact with everything in the area and not only is there consequences for the NPC's but for the player as well. Which makes it a fun replayable game unlike the novelist.Bottom line The Novelist is recommended for people who want to buy gifts for people they hate.Recommendations for people who want an actual game with a proper story and game play; "To The Moon" it's like a 16 bit RPG with puzzles instead of random turn based battles.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Allow me to preface my review with this: I very much enjoyed the time I spent with The Novelist and I think that it signifies a good first step for Orthogonal Games as a developer. However, I cannot recommend the game at full price (at the time of this review said price point is 14.99 USD).     The environment takes on a simplistic and limited asthetic, confining the player to the workspace of a small two story house. Despite the house's intended purpose being to signify a new beginning for Dan and his family I couldn't help but feel that the house was in someway devoid of life. My first instinct was to blame the very "samey" colour pallet that The Novelist employs. However, the more I think on it the more I believe it has to do with the fact that the characters simply do not interact with the environment around them; save for very minor things such as Dan using his typewritter. The house is a stage, but the actors refuse to make use of the props.      The system of making choices is thankfully simple, however, so too are the choices themselves. Many of the choices felt as though they were not meaningful in the long run. There were a few occasions where the choices did not conflict with eachother or could easily be done in conjunction with eachother; which is counterintuitive to the very idea of only being able to make one choice and a halfhearted compromise with another. As a result of the simplicity many of the choices outcomes, and indeed the overarching story's outcome, were entirely too predictable. In fact, the bits of story that I found most interesting were the short moments spent discovering the history of the house.     The stealth mechanic gets in the way of the game's strongest asset: The story. However, there is not enough occuring during the segments of the game where the player is allowed to freely roam that keep the game interesting without it.      The story, and indeed the writing itself, are of a simplistic nature and are somewhat interesting. However, the characters themselves felt more like fassades for the player to toy with than fully fledged individuals. As a result the story, at times, feels rather dull. There are interesting directions that the game could have been taken that were simply ignored or declined.     Overall The Novleist culminated into an interesting and somewhat enjoyable experience. However, as stated above, I could not recommend it at full price. With a steep sale? Certainly.And as a personal aside: You absolutely do not have to be a parent to "get" this game. There is absolutely nothing to be gained from having a child of your own that you would not get otherwise. The greatest benefit I could see coming from having a child of your own would be a slightly stronger emotional connection with Dan. However, should you not be living a life blessed by comfort and ease at every turn, you should find it easy to make this same emotional connection if you do not have a child of your own. The most significant conflict in The Novelist is the act of balancing the many facets of a person's life, not the arbitrary ideals of what it is to be a parent.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Moving in surprising ways, The Novelist is an excellent game for those who enjoy recent indie jams like To The Moon or Always Sometimes Monsters. At its very core, it is a game about choice that defies simplistic morality models ("tap the blue text to be GOOD, tap the red text to be EEEEVIL"). With apologies to excellent games like Mass Effect or Dragon Age, the decisions you are presented with in The Novelist cut against such black and white notions of the world. Each choice you are faced with is microcosmic. Each one lacks that "save the world or watch it burn!" weight that seems second nature to games. Not that this nature is bad. I only say this to bring attention to the fact that, while the decisions in The Novelist appear on the surface to be so small-scale, they feel incredibly impactful. This game is, on many levels, proof that the big, dramatic moral decisions in many choose-your-morality video games today are the EASY decisions.On another level, this is a game about..playing a game. Rather than take on the central characters as avatars, you float around in a demi-god mode, critically affecting their lives as you go. This distance between you and the characters is brave in and of itself because playing through that distanced demi-god mode makes you choose just how close to or estranged from these characters you wish to be.Mechanically, the game is sound and easy to control. The eccentricities of the challenge involved in "stealth mode" (where you must go undetected by the family) do not impede enjoyment of the game (it is always very fair). The voice acting is not amazing, but it is good. And the art style is pleasant to look at without obvious glitches or whatsthats that might pull you out of the game.

												An absolute gem of a playable novel. You can tell that the creator has poured years of his love, frustration and inspiration into this work, and it pays off. The three voice actors are brilliant, and the scripts are so realistically well done. The emotional connection you inevitably - and suprisingly quickly - create with not only the main characters, but also tenants of the 'haunted' house from the long distant past, will leave you in tears or at least vocally voicing your joy or sorrow at each twist and turn of their fates that your ghostly character has helped to shape.I've almost exclusively played this game in Story Mode so far, and I would recommend to do so for maximum replayability and exploration of the different storylines you can travel down. Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game, seemingly based somewhat on Woolf's novel 'To the Lighthouse,' was a marvelous experience. While it is heavily story based and has multiple endings, it DOES have gameplay, unlike some of the Indie walking simulators that you find. However, you'd have to be really silly to actually get punished for failing to do a good job with the gameplay, I feel. Still, it's enough to keep you actually playing the game while watching the story unravel according to your actions.The game highlights some of the same existencial issues that 'To the Lighthouse' does: it highlights family and relationship issues in day-to-day living, and the problems balancing work with the two. It also shows that the lives of all people invovled are transient and fleeting, and all that's left of us afterwards is our art: whether it be the books we write or the paintings we craft. The shared symbol of the lighthouse and some of the shared activities of both families gives them both the same ambiance, I felt. Regardless, definitely look into this one, as it leaves you something to learn and ponder about your own life.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												I can dig it. It's definitely not for everyone, but if you like unique ways of story-telling and don't mind if the gameplay suffers a bit because of it - though the story doesn't seem to be special by any means - then you might should give this a go. The User Reviews are Mostly Positive. I don't believe I've ever seen a game with 5+ reviews rated as either strictly Positive or Negative; thus, The Novelist is... just above average, as it were. I agree with that assessment. That second sentence seems to contradict itself, but I find the game as a whole to be sum-how greater than it's parts (teehee). The story is one of a family on the verge. From the game's tutorial, it seems the father is the priority. You are some sort of entity; it is implied at the end of the first night that  you are, basically, a ghost haunting the house. Your purpose is to play implicit life-coach for the residents. The father is a struggling author what wanted to get away from it all and make things simple so as to better concentrate on his work. The mother is a fretful wife who makes better use of the solitude of the rented vacation home by painting, all the while yearning to bridge the rift that's formed between her and her partner. The child is a son wondering about this thing called "life," wanting to be a kid, to spend time with Dad, to be just like Mom.You do not wish to let the family know of your presence. You can possess light fixtures to move about the house and can walk freely when the coast is clear. There are notes, letters and images to read and view strewn throughout the house. From these - and from the thoughts of the people themselves' - you can gain insight into their relationships and into their pertinent desires. If they are between you and one of the papers, you can cause the light fixture you're currently possessing to flicker, so as to distract. If they catch a glimpse of you, they apparently become wary (to say the least) and are less susceptible to your methods.There are two difficulties to choose from: Stealth and Story. The former necessitates the use of traveling from light fixture to fixture, the latter renders the game a walking simulator. Having picked Stealth, I have been in plain view, albeit a bit to the side, of the people and (as far as I can tell) not been detected. Maybe their cones of vision are something like... 37°. This is to call into question the integrity of The Novelist as a game.After having learned as much as there is to presently, you can go into each individual's memories and glean a bit more from a few snippets. Upon exiting their mind, you can read their thoughts once more and discover what their wish (end-goal for the chapter) is, what item you must collect for it. If you find all of the notes and memories of either or both of the other two - once you make your primary decision -- once everybody goes to bed --- you can, both, scour the house for notes that reveal the history of the house (and of you) and find the item for a secondary objective; you whisper your decisions into the man's ear and get a cutscene explaining the consequences of that compromise. There will always be at least one family member that doesn't get what they want/(")need("). This is a game about the balancing of relationships, of choices, of stealth... and of being creepy.I have spent minutes just staring at people sleeping and hanging out in bathrooms... just waiting...Ha. And again. ha.Seriously: If any of that sounds interesting - and I don't know how it can't, at least in theory - I recommend you at least try the game. I will say that some will NOT find the product to be executed as well as the premise suggests, when considering that it's a video game; either find the gameplay to be lacking, or the story (which is the focus) to be too mundane.Indeed, the one YouTube personality I follow - Jim Sterling - holds the opinion that, too often, walking simulators commit the crime of telling rather than showing; of having the game focus on, i.e., the aftermath of a much more interesting event than the one you, as the player, are involved in, i.e. learning of the event afterwards. Though this specific critique couldn't be laid on this game, I feel the core complaint is the very essence of The Novelist. Though you influence the outcomes, you are not directly involved in the story at all, and are thus a glorified camera-person.EDIT: Practically, $15 is far too substantial an asking price. Not to suggest that the work put into the game isn't worth that, but it is to say that, as a gamer, I can tell my fellows that there are more competitive titles in the Market, though I will concede that many of those have even less traditional gameplay (i.e. mechanics that make them more'n walking simulators / visual novels (not that there's anything inherently wrong with either, but to say that there's a difference between story-driven games and games built to tell a story... yeah, so the latter might be written as "(")games(")"))... I'd wait for at least a 25% off sale.

Posted: November 16, 2014
												I'll start by saying that I don't have children and don't have contact with my family.  Not in a bad way, I'm just a deeply selfish person.  My wife and I would rather soend our money on holidays, games and cats than anything serious like bringing up a child.  What's the point of this surprisingly personal and seemingly irrelevant disclosure?  Well, despite my shortcomings as an adult human, I loved The Novelist.The Novelist is a game that will mean something different to every person who plays it, depending on their point of view.  The way the game plays is that a small family have rented a house for the summer - the father sees it as an opportunity to work on his book, the wife sees it as a chance to rebuild their failing relationship and it is supposed to be a chance to address the problem the son has at school.  You play as a spirit that haunts the house and it is up to you to influence the father at the end of each day as to how to handle an event (or events) that will affect the family.  You do this by gathering information on each person's take on the event and coming to a conclusion as to how best to handle it.  Find every piece of information, and you will be allowed a compromise at the end of the day, meaning that one person will come away happy with the result, one placated and one potentially unhappy.This is all simply done, and can be played as either a casual point and click style game of (admittedly limited) exploration, or as an stealth-lite game that has you trying to avoid the family seeing you, and thus becoming spooked and denying you the ability to come to a compromise with them.  Playing this way is actually quite engaging and adds a light air of tension added to by the lack of saves during the day, meaning you have to live with your decisions and mistakes.Although I found myself drawn to the characters, it wasn't necessarily through their actual interactions.  If anything, that would be the weakest part of the game.  The characters' personalities are all explored very well through diaries and journals, but doesn't come across in the world of the game.  It can be argued that it adds to the otherworldly feel to the game, but I think a lot would be added by the characters showing more... well... character.Anyway returning to my opening paragraph - I felt when I started the game that I would absolutely be on the father's side.  The game is called The Novelist, he is earning the money in the family and the house was rented to allow him to work on his book.  So, fine.  Cut and dried, let's get this book printed!  Well, no.  Reading the wife's personal thoughts and fears about how close to divorce they are without him realising was actually quite scary.OK.  Let's focus on the relationship and put the book on the sidelines, the kid will be fine.  The outcome of my first decision showed that the child was disappointed and I could live with that.  What I couldn't live with, was seeing him devastated at the next outcome screen.  So, well done, game!  I felt bad and went about actually making decisions for the good of the family as a whole.As I played, it actually took me back to a holiday where my own father had to take time to study through it, something I haven't thought about in years, and realised that the developer absolutely nailed the scenario.  I actually found myself sympathetic towards each member in the family.  I wasn't working towards some winning gamestate at the end, but toward a scenario that would make everything OK for them all.  I was drawn in completely.I obviously had a deeply personal connection to the game, so would it stand up without that?  I don't see why not.  It is short enough that it can even make a nice talking point if you play with another person as well.  On the whole, it is easy to recommend this game - I won't deny that you need you need a degree of empathy and maturity to fully apreciate it, but that's no bad thing.

												When I think of words to describe this "game" the ones that come to mind are: depressing, annoying, boring, repetitive and tedious. I did like the look and graphics but the overall lack of variability or any sense of fun made me just want to get to the finish quickly,

Posted: April 5, 2015
												This game has some flaws. Maybe, the gameplay is a bit redundant and overall repetitive. The graphics are rather simple (not ugly, simple!) and there is a low density of details. True.On the other side there is a game that is pretty heart shacking and intellectual challenging. The game is basic, but that has its meaning because it focuses you on the story, the characters, the development and, most of all, your decision! This game is simple, but it is maybe the game where your decisions have the greatest impact on the development of the story. Therefore, not only “the novelist” is not “not a game” – it pushes the idea of controlling the story, not only its outcome, in a progressive direction. That this can’t be without flaws in the performance. But a game doesn’t have to be perfectly save, to be good. Any experiment has its mixed outcomes. And therefor, “The Novelist” should be played because of its great outcome AND because of its flaws.

And - The Son = A kid stuck between a struggling marriage and was just moved from his old house. I think he had a friend back in the old town he misses or maybe his Bro died, because he has a few crayon drawings of him and another kid.           AAAAAAAAAAAAANnnnnyyy Way. You go through and pick the outcomes of who gets what they want at the end of each chapter. The only logical choice at the end of each chapter is the kids happiness over the mom and dad's. If the parents would have some sort of common sense they wouldn't be worried about themselves and do whatever it takes to take care of the kid. Yeah didn't play the entire game so there could be some sort of better story going on. But I can't sit through and make the kid unhappy for two childish seeming adults. Thanks to anyone that read, goodnight.

Posted: December 7, 2014
												When I first heard about a game, where you play as a writer trying to balance concerns for his family against the demands of his deadlines I was intrigued, but not quite enough for the price tag. I'm glad I waited for a sale, because I find the game very mediocre. The most serious problem is that the very simplistic gameplay elementels don't suit the narrative structure that is the game's main selling point. Basically it a single level repetitive 1st person stealth game. You are a ghost that must remain unseen, explore the house in which the Kaplan family of three lives, read their thoughts and letters. Then brain wash the titular novelist in his sleep so that he will make the decision you find most appropriate. If that hasn't deterred you from trying out the game I'd advise you to wait for a sale to grab it. It's can be completed in 1½-2 hours or much less you disable stealth and don't explore each chapter. It can be longer if you wish to replay it. But I don't find it interesting enough for a replay. There are better story driven games out there, stronger in both narrative, emotional depth and gameplay, even all at once, whereas this game is pretty lackluster in all these aspects.

												Go around making choices as a conscience ghost moving through lights. It was okay. The house is pretty bland and the same type of music all the time can get irritating. But its kinda fun making all the choices that affect everyone. You decide the outcome of the story. I give it a 6/10

Posted: December 11, 2014
												The idea for this game had promise, but in the end anyone could stand back to see the big picture, and that picture is that it was poorly executed. Essentially this is a game where you're constantly balancing happiness levels between Human A, human B, and human C. The problem is you can only please two people each round, so you have to take it in turns to see who gets left out. In the end this game just gives you the illusion of free will. This is The Sims with less interactivity

Posted: February 2, 2015
												The Novelist is an interesting take on the interactive novel genre. You play a ghostly presence that lives in a summer getaway house, inhabited by a struggling novelist, his wife and young son. Gameplay is minimal, limited to spooking around the a house by possessing lightbulbs, taking care not to be seen by the family. As you flit around the house, you investigate clues left by the various members of the family, which you can use to influence the novelist's decisions and the future of the family.The game lasts about 2.5 hours if you dig into everyone's stories, but that's not counting replays to get the various endings. It is well written and the characters feel believable (even if the fact that they hang around the house all day doesn't feel particularly realistic!). Worth a look for fans of interactive stories or quiet games that don't involve a lot of stress!www.goplaythat.com

Posted: December 4, 2014
												If I were to compare it to other games, the Novelist would be in the same vein as Dear Esther, Stanley Parable, and Proteus.  Technically they're games, but not ones that most gamers are familiar with.  The draw of the Novelist is more in the story and presentation than in the game mechanic.  There is the stealth aspect to the game, which increases the difficulty for collecting clues that are essential for influencing the ending, but it can be turned off by those who don't want to deal with it, thus why this game is considered casual.  Toggling this option is available at anytime in the settings and having it off or on does not have any impact on the ending.  Also there are no achievements in the game so completing the game only in stealth is only a personal reward.  The only reason for playing with stealth mode is to increase the difficulty of the game for those looking for a challenge as being spotted at anytime will limit choices that alter the ending.  Unfortunately, the small, unchanging environment will probably not interest players for long as it will begin to feel reptitive after a few scenes.  I personally turned it off after a while.In other words, play Novelist not for the game mechanic but for the story it presents.  How well rated the story is depends on how much gamers resonate with the Kaplan family.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												The designer for this game left his job working with huge teams to make an entire game by himself, and it shows. I'm glad I bought the game because I have hope that the money he's made with this game will lead to something worth playing in the future, but this ain't it.The script gives the illusion of choice, but you're following a narrow path with gameplay that is little more than hide and seek. I bought the game hoping for a compelling storyline, but it rarely reached beyond evenly distributing attention into three buckets, with a unsatisfyingly easy end.The whole game is half an hour long with no reply value. Buy the game, download it for an afternoon, then save the room on your computer content that you just donated money to a good cause.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												A great balancing act between one's dreams and obligations. True to life, the conflicts that arise between a man and his family cause a sense of gravity and depth for every decision and, more importantly, omission.I personally recommend playing in Story mode before trying "stealth" mode. That way you can soak yourself in the narrative and not worry about being stealthy. Highly recommended for people who are drawn to narrative driven games like Stanley Parable, Gone Home, The Walking Dead and Dear Esther.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												I voted for this game to be Greenlit and was happy to see that it has mostly lived up to the potential it showed then. You play some sort of ghost or spirit that inhabits a house which a writer named Dan and his wife and son rent for the summer so that Dan can focus on working on his next book.  The game is divided into several chapters as the spirit you have to move throughout the house reading letters, reading the family members thoughts and exploring their memories to find out the desires of each family member. You do all this while trying to remain undetected (though if you want to focus on the story you can turn the requirement for stealth off). When you've uncovered each family members desire you have to pick one and whisper it to Dan so it is acted upon. The family member who's desire you picked will be happy but the other two will not. At the end of the chapter after you've made your choice you get to see the outcomes on each character and it is quite difficult to see the negative outcomes as you do end up feeling sorry for them. It's a pity the game doesn't have more solutions that would satisfy more than one character so your decision can become an agonizing choice.The real strength of this game is the story it weaves about the family. You get to know each character and how they feel through their memories and the letters you read and while the story this game tells about them is the typical trials and tribulations of a family, it's done so well that you do end up caring about them and that makes the choices you make that bit more agonizing. The only downside of this game is that the exploration side where you move about the house trying to find letters and look through the families memories gets boring after a short while as it gets repetitive doing more less the same thing in every chapter. Overall though this is a great story based games that will please people who enjoyed games like Gone Home and Dear Esther. It's a 7/10 from me.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												Another interesting indie game.It is short -- about 1 1/2 hours per playthrough, but it lends itself to multiple playthroughs. The game is about choice -- when there are three characters with three different goals (a husband with his career, a wife and her career, and a son with difficulties in school), what is the right choice to make? Often the answer is complex, and there is no right answer. Give up to much for your family, and you might end up resenting your family. I recommend, if you are into the indie/story based plots, or interested in how choice can be done in video games. Compare the choices/outcomes in this game with Fallout, Mass Effect, and Walking Dead.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												A slick little indie number, with an emotionally complex core, that forces you to make realistic decisions and live with the consequences - all while remaining hidden from the family. Fantastic blend of story telling and decision making.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game, seemingly based somewhat on Woolf's novel 'To the Lighthouse,' was a marvelous experience. While it is heavily story based and has multiple endings, it DOES have gameplay, unlike some of the Indie walking simulators that you find. However, you'd have to be really silly to actually get punished for failing to do a good job with the gameplay, I feel. Still, it's enough to keep you actually playing the game while watching the story unravel according to your actions.The game highlights some of the same existencial issues that 'To the Lighthouse' does: it highlights family and relationship issues in day-to-day living, and the problems balancing work with the two. It also shows that the lives of all people invovled are transient and fleeting, and all that's left of us afterwards is our art: whether it be the books we write or the paintings we craft. The shared symbol of the lighthouse and some of the shared activities of both families gives them both the same ambiance, I felt. Regardless, definitely look into this one, as it leaves you something to learn and ponder about your own life.

Posted: November 11, 2014
												It's quite more then a game, it's a immersive reflexive experience where you play as a 'something' (maybe a ghost) that analisis every events, thoughts and memories of each one of the three characters of a tradicional family and take the decisions for the father of the family. You can choose between take care more of your son's progress in school and life or incentivate your wife emotions, turning her hobby in a carreer or you can choose dedicate to your own book writting spending some selfish time for your personal growning. Every and each decision you whisper at the father of the family   affects the whole family during the progress of the game so then you have to be carefull in what sacrifice take in behalf of what character to accomplish the happiness of everybody.The fact of the game presenting multiple endings (and so much) it's really impressive because it take in consideration every decision taken since the game starts and make me question: is there a bad ending or it just the way people find happiness that is different one of other?The interesting thing you can notice is if you are not a father/mother and husband/wife you can have a notion of where you would be going if you were one and if you actually already are you will notice where you are going choosing your priorities or not instead or your family.It's a deep, reflexive, philosophical, short, "non-replayable", conscientizing, real game that primary focus on our nowadays decisions as a family integrant.How not to recomend?

												I am currently enjoying the game to the fullest and find that it has amazing replayablity to it as well, seeing as how you can always have a different outcome depending upon what you pick. 												The art is great, and reminiscent of oil paintings (especially the scenery outside). The story is what drives the game, but I feel it has it's challenges. Posted: January 14, 2015
												Like most games it has its good points as well as bad points, and this is all opinion based. The story is rather simple, predictable, and sometimes does not make much sense; the graphics are pretty sterile too. I found some of the characters (mostly the wife so far) to be faulted to the point where I kinda wanted as a ghost to come down and slap them a bit. But, I found the idea of playing  helpful ghost very unique and interesting. And it shows a glimpse into some of the pressures a professional writer can have (the idea that yes i am home, no i can't devote the entirety of my time to you i do have to work). The game is very atmospheric with a slow almost sad tone to everything from the voices to the music. unfortunately for me because of that sad atmosphere I can't play much. If you suffer from depression I'd recommend caution with the game, but otherwise its refreshing and enjoyable.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												Overall, this felt just far too contrived for me to ever really connect to. A huge part of it is that it's tough to link to the sympathy of the character difficulties because its all based on what is, ultimately, feeling like some sort of rich/upper-class background where the choices center around one character a professional writer, one character wanting to be a professional artist, and the needs of their kid. The choices that have to get made at that point just start to feel ridiculous. Each week there's multiple days off, they're traveling to have a summer 'off' working, and so to be in that situation and still not being able to manage compromises like "read to the kid and work" just feels ridiculously absurd to me.Beyond that, the whole game just gets repetitive. Each time is walk around, find all the clues, making a fairly arbitrary choice, and then repeating the whole thing another dozen times. It wouldn't be so bad if that changed up location each time, but for being in that location the whole time, the limited scope and repetitive motions got tiresome. The controls for getting around also were pretty frustrating, as there's an interesting attempt at using lights as a way to jump from place to place in the house, but it really didn't work well and often got in the way. It really could have benefited from better control design, so that space wasn't required for everything, and sometimes even to carry out different actions on the same things.The lasting disappointment for me is that there was an indication that there's an underlying backstory to the game that was never resolved, and hinted at something interesting. Instead, the game ended with a "where are they now" type ending that felt far too overblown, and stems from that same mindset going into the character backgrounds, that they can't just be moderately successful, but that it had to be to some grandiose extent. It just comes across as overdone, and not exploring something that could've had a lot more potential.Really couldn't recommend it, it drags along without packing much punch.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												A game that gets to the heart of what it means to be a good person.  It's a question I've wrestled with my entire life.  There is a line-- somewhere, for everyone-- that has to be drawn.  When do you stop helping other people and start helping yourself?  You can always be helping other people.  You could be doing it right now, but you're not.  You're reading this.  To find a game that forces you to make those decisions is both welcoming and painful.  I played it straight through, and I won't tell you the ending I received, but it's probably obvious.  I would imagine that Jesus had to take time for himself.  I would imagine Jesus wanted to escape from everything and be alone his entire life because it decreases the obligation and the guilt that goes along with not helping others.  But he kept helping.  And died for it.  I guess there's a quiet beauty in that.

Not As Pretentious As I Thought!Look, most art-games are non-games. I'm happy to report that this fits MY definition of a game. You can... no, you WILL make the wrong decisions. Constantly. And that is what makes this game so powerful. My favourite aspect of the gameplay was that the play can decide on how much to immerse themselves in the story, or the plight of certain characters. Apart from this, the game has a beautifully eery atmosphere in which you might feel spooked for a moment before you remember that you are the spectre in this game - threw me off a few times.This game is not for everyone, but I believe the situations depicted in the game make for a gripping experience for most people. Bare in mind that I went into this game with low expectations and was pleasantly surprised. Either way, no bugs, ran smoothly, easy to control and had simplistic controls. Don’t skip tutorial or tips; they only appear once.Long story short, I had fun with it, don’t expect too much of it, but give it a fair go if you are game.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												In The Novelist, you play a meddling ghost that seemingly cares about the family renting your summer home, but actually doesn't give a darn what they want, leaving you to invade their minds and choose their life paths for them.Skulking around from room to room, you discover clues to what Dan (a struggling author), Linda (an once and possibly future painter), and Tommy (lonely child) want to do that week. You then can choose whose desire is most important and go that route. Afterward, still images show the fallout of your 'wisdom.'At nighttime, you can seek clues granting additional insight to the house and your role, and you can creepily hover over the sleeping family and listen to their dream thoughts.This game offers two modes, but I don't know what the developer was thinking. This isn't Splinter Cell -- skip the stealth mode, and focus on the story. After all, what's the fun in ruining-- I mean, guiding lives if your ghostly powers can be stripped from you by being spotted?-----Time to put on my serious pants. I think the premise of The Novelist is brilliant, and there are some powerful moments, but the choices often ring artificial. There were a handful of times that all three members could have compromised, but -- as per the game's rules -- only two of three could be chosen. Also, there were moments where it seemed like there would be positive gains for one or more family members, only for negative ramifications to be thrown in your face because the game's writer didn't think things through.Finally, the endings -- especially Tommy's -- seemed at odds with his own personality, let alone some of the story paths.And that whole stealth mode nonsense...Basically, The Novelist is interesting and worth a playthrough, but I can't really call it good. Nonetheless, I'd at least recommend it if you can nab it for a deep discount. On September 8, 2015, it was $2.24 and I think adventure and narrative fans would absolutely get their money's worth.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												A man takes his wife & young son to a secluded vacation home so that he can focus on writing his next great novel; little do they know that the house is also home to an unknown supernatural force that can worm its way into the father's mind. No, it's not The Shining, it's The Novelist. In it you play a spirit (or something?? it's not actually specified) haunting a house on a cliff. Your goal is to influence the choices of the father/husband character, Dan, by learning as much as you can about him & his family through written & drawn clues scattered around the house as well as by entering each character's memories. Each chapter presents a situation to which there are three solutions: one that most benefits the dad, one the mom, & one the kid. You can also make a secondary "compromise" choice that will at least partially satisfy one of the other characters if not totally please them.If "Stealth" mode is enabled you have the potential of being spotted by the family while you gather clues during the day, which causes you to lose certain opportunities. You can become invisible & move from one place to the next without being seen by possessing the home's light fixtures, but you can't gather clues when you're in a lamp, so you also have the ability to make a light flicker to distract the family away from where you want to go. There is an alternate "Story" mode where you are invisible no matter where you are. In both modes there are some situations where characters will close doors on you (usually if they're mad about being neglected); you can't open or pass through the doors but the family usually opens them again soon enough. There's a subplot that involves gathering clues about the house's past, but that is not mutable based on the player's choices so it feels more like filler material.The gameplay is fairly straightforward, if a little tedious at times. Think "Gone Home" in a scaled-down form. The graphics are quite lovely, especially the vistas visible through the windows. Several people have singled out the voice acting as exceptional but I didn't find anything remarkable about it. The plot is... okay. I didn't care much for any of the characters, but I still wanted to make good choices for them. There are multiple happy endings & sad endings possible, although not very many, & none too exciting (certainly nothing close to The Shining in that respect!).Overall though this was a nice game to spend a bit of time on; it's pretty relaxing & there's definitely not anything high stress about it. I enjoyed playing through making choices "organically" the first time & then running through it quicker in subsequent replays to get different outcomes. I would definitely recommend doing "Stealth" mode for your first playthrough to get the most out of the experience; enable "Story" for replays so you can move from choice to choice & clue to clue much quicker & don't have to deal with spending time on repeated material. It goes quickly enough when you do that.Even though it would seem there's a lot of responsibility on your shoulders, spending time in this game's world really is soothing, & having different options & routes to take is fun. I like that it's an indie game too. I am happy with my purchase -- but, after all, I bought it on sale, which I would recommend.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												Relaxing but engaging game with a pretty neat choose your own adventure type feel to it.  Read a few other reviews before writing this so there's a few things I would like to point out as a pseudo-response.  I played this on the "stealth" required mode, which was not difficult nor tedious; you get a feel for it rather quickly and it adds an element of suspense to your actions throughout the game.  I imagine that it could be rather slow and repetetive for those playing on the "story" only mode.  The story overall was pretty neat, you get some insights into the history of the house you are in, the Kaplan's wants and needs (from each individual's perspective and that of their family members), and maybe even backstory on the entity you play as.  Most of the negative reviews I read seemed to take the story and characters... too seriously maybe? It's an indie game. the writing and character development isn't going to be spot on flawless all the time, but for the most part it was good.  Each chapter made me think a bit before I chose a way to end it, none were absolute no brainers, though there was the occasional obvious best and worst choices.  I rarely play games over to seek out different endings but with this one, I might.  Feels like you have some actual agency and I found my opinion of each character developing as the story progressed.  It's about 2hrs long and makes for a good lazy/tired morning/evening game.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												An inteligent game (experience?) in which you attempt to influence and balance the aspirations and emotions of Dan (Husband and writer), Linda (Wife and artist), Tommy (Son) while they have a summer retreat to try to help Dan write his latest book. You can choose to support one character in each chapter (level?) of the game, and then if you havn't been spotted you have the chance of picking one of two possible compromises.The balancing act of trying to keep everyone happy allthewhile trying to get Dan's book finished is a tough one indeed.There are two game modes (difficulties), one which I refer to as stalker mode, which is the tougher mode, in which you have to avoid being spotted. Or story mode, in which you can just concentrate on the story side of things.If you enjoy the likes of inteligent games/experiences such as Dear Esther and Ether One, then The Novelist will be right up your alley. But if you are looking for non-stop action and shooting suff (Eagle, flag, explosions, "'Merica") then you would be better looking elsewhere.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												This game, seemingly based somewhat on Woolf's novel 'To the Lighthouse,' was a marvelous experience. While it is heavily story based and has multiple endings, it DOES have gameplay, unlike some of the Indie walking simulators that you find. However, you'd have to be really silly to actually get punished for failing to do a good job with the gameplay, I feel. Still, it's enough to keep you actually playing the game while watching the story unravel according to your actions.The game highlights some of the same existencial issues that 'To the Lighthouse' does: it highlights family and relationship issues in day-to-day living, and the problems balancing work with the two. It also shows that the lives of all people invovled are transient and fleeting, and all that's left of us afterwards is our art: whether it be the books we write or the paintings we craft. The shared symbol of the lighthouse and some of the shared activities of both families gives them both the same ambiance, I felt. Regardless, definitely look into this one, as it leaves you something to learn and ponder about your own life.

Posted: May 13, 2016
												The Novelist is a game that falls into that bucket of games that aren't exactly interactive experiences like Dear Esther, but still not nearly as involved gameplay wise as the majority of mainstream FPS games.  The title sees you patrolling the Summer home of a frustrated author and his single unit family as some sort of "presence" or "ghost".  There are two distinct game "difficulties", in the first you can patrol the house on foot (I assume its on foot, the player's avatar is still a bit of a mystery reserved for hints found in the notes scattered through the levels) without the NPC's noticing you.  The second takes on a more stealth-based approach, requiring you to hide from the family as you peruse through their thoughts and belongings.  Basic gameplay involves you searching through the house and possessing the thoughts of the family to determine what the hopes, needs and feelings are of each family member.  You can navigate through traditional walking or via possession of light fixtures.  After you discover enough information to continue, you can either stick around to get the rest of the missing information, or make a decision on how to influence the father's thoughts.  After a you commit to your choices, the house switches to night, where you can discover notes relating the experiences of past denizens of the house and finally pass your decisions on to the father.  The story threads hinge very much on which characters you choose to make happy at the end of each day, and the choices directly effect the NPC's moods and relationships with each other as the Summer progresses.  You can go the route of making everyone as happy as possible, or focus only on the needs of a single family member depending on your decisions.  The house looks pretty and has just enough detail in it for you to have to search for clues during the day without getting lost in the clutter.  For a game that depends a lot on moods, the characters have somewhat blank painted-like faces, a smart decision on their part as now the characters con convey their mood via body language instead of heavily involved face posing.  As someone entering the working world trying to balance time between family, career, and hobbies, the game really clicked with me conceptually, and though its very subtle in its pace and approach to gameplay, I still found myself enjoying it for the duration of a Saturday afternoon.  Length (~3 hours) may be a consideration for some, so waiting for a discount might make it more of a bang for your buck.
