												A while back, I received this game among a bunch of others in a Humble Bundle. Since this isn't typically the genre of game that I play, I added it to my library and promptly forgot about it. Just a few days ago, upon noticing the game in my library, I installed it with the intent of farming some steam trading cards and deleting it afterwards.Allow me to say that I am *SO* glad that curriosity got the better of me and I decided to give the game a try. In complete honesty, I can say that I don't think I've ever become so emotionally invested in a game's fictional family as I did with the Kaplans.This being said, I would recommend that anyone playing this game should play it in Story mode as opposed to Stealth mode. The stealth mechanic can get a bit annoying and clunky, while also making the Kaplans' stories that much less immersive than you building/observing their lives free-rein. This puts a greatter emphasis on the game's "Story-Rich" tag, and less on the "Stealth" tag, which in turn--I believe--plays to its strengths.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game promised a narrative-focused, decision-making stealth game. And that's exactly what it was.I've only played it once, but I always got the sense that things would turn out differently if I made different choices for the family, and more importantly, that things would go very bad if I made the wrong choices.If I would critique anything, it would be that the characters seemed a bit bland and overly sensitive to what are ostensibly first-world-problems.That, and the detective-work mechanics were a bit too easy. They got the point across, but in similar games like Gone Home, you really feel like you're digging through other people's business and feel a bit apprehensive about what you mind find. All those things in consideration, I enjoyed flitting around the house as a ghost and debating which family member to help when. If I were an indie developer, I'd be proud to have made something this tight on the first try.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												The Novelist is a touching and thoughful narrative game, which despite its simplistic mechanics and presentation manages to pose some genuinely challenging moral questions to the player. The game lacks some polish, with many aspects feeling rather clunky, and the gameplay is very much secondary to the narrative (to the point that the main gameplay mechanic - avoiding being spotted by the family - can actually be switched off so you can relax and enjoy the narrative), but the honesty of the game more than makes up for this.I would recommend this game for anyone looking for an unusually genuine and heartful narrative experience (think The Beginners Guide, Gone Home etc.), and who is willing to see past its rough edges to get the most from the experience.

Posted: November 26, 2016
A touching little game with choices that actually matter "The Novelist" is one of the few games that keep their promise of offering several choices with an actual impact on the story's outcome. It also is one of the few games that leave you with a strange feeling in your stomach. Through the protagonist's actions and mistakes you can learn a lot about your own character, your life goals, what you are doing with the time you've got on this planet and how you treat the people you love.I really like games that actually encourage you to start thinking in a deeper way. That's why I'll definitely recommend it to anyone who is open to questions like this.In "The Novelist" you are going to face daily problems almost ever young family encounters nowadays, thankfully without any kitsch, unrealistic "happy ends" or over-the top dramatic situations. All the characters are understandable, there is no villain or bad seed. And you will never be able to please everybody with your decisions. Just like in real life. That's what makes this game so special.The gameplay itself isn't much of a challenge - there is a "stealth"-mode, but not getting spotted isn't actually hard. So don't expect a hardcore game full of adrenaline and high speed. The graphics are in a "Firewatch"-like style, simple, but pleasant to the eye. Same goes for the music.But beware: you should be ready to read a lot, otherwise you'll get bored very soon. As a quick reader, my first game took approximately 2-3 hours, but seeing all the different endings and reactions requires several playthroughs. And if that's not enough for you, you can always buy it at a discount.

Posted: November 9, 2014
												The Novelist is one of the greastest game storytelling games out there. You won't find another diamond like this one.Pros: 1) The story and theme are crafted to perfection. Everything makes logical sense. The characters are simple to understand and grasp. You're intrigued at every time whether it's by curiousity, suspense, hard choices, and/or personal reactions to the result. There are backstories that don't affect the main one which increase morals taught and entertainment. I personally joyed over the latter effect obviously. To avoid spoilers, I won't go further.2) The graphics are great and there is no lag. Even though the game itself is more important than graphics, this can be a good plus.3) The controls feel comfortable and reasonable.4) Anyone who aided in making this creation seemed well credited especially advisors and programs. Cons: 1) The stealth may feel repetitious if you're not interested into the story, but I must say it's a bit fun, and it makes sense when the video game is based more on story than sneaking; otherwise, it wouldn't have been as great. A harder challenge feels worse with a terrible reward.2) It involved a lot of reading, but I definitely enjoyed myself when the pace was mixed with stealth. Overall, I have no regrets. If you want to hear an excellent story while pacing the reading with sneaking, buy this game. In the case that you are purely looking for a stealth game challenge, then I would reconsider. I hope the dev continues making games as great as this one, and even if he didn't, at least he created The Novelist.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												I did not expect much from the game. It does not have the best game play, mechanics, graphics, writing or anything really. Yet even after a year I still occasionally think about the choices I made and the message the game delivers. Slow burn! I think, that is how good art should work. Thank you.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												You play as supernatural being, genius loci, who can influence family living in your house. Story arc is split to 12 chapters, and in each chapter all 3 family members want different things. You can only side with one them and make compromise with other; third end up unhappy.Your task is... well, it's up for you. Do you want to help little Tommy grow up happy and creative person? Do you want Dan to be successful writer? May be it's Lisa who you feel for? Or may be you want them all to be happy family? You can do all that.The game is pretty short, can be beaten in one evening, but replayability is quite good, since you can try achieve different goals.As for downsides, 1) gameplay is pretty easy (difficulty mode like "Nightmare" could improve that) and 2) voice acting could be better sometimes.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												The concept is nice. But gameplay is boring. I quit after 3 chapters.You are limited to one house and 3 persons.You are a ghost who has to learn their thoughts. This is obtained by standing behind them and pressing space bar.To get the requered thought to get further in the story you also have to find notes, pictures and objects. So you go from one room to the other and just look and click. There are no puzzles and you don't have to solve any riddles or anything. Just point and click. At the end you'll get to make the decision if the husband will follow the desire of  wife, kid or his own. But whatever you do, the decision leaves 2 people malcontent. e.g. if you play with the kid, the wife is not happy you don't support her career and the husband is not happy because he misses deathlines for his book. Kind of stupid.The Sims are more realistic on human relations.

												I recieved this  game as a gift, someone had recived it in a HumbleBundle and didn't want it. What a mistake on their part. It's not hard but captures attention all the same. I like being a ghost.

Posted: November 13, 2016
												Visual story non-game with slice-of-life kind of plot. If you enjoyed Life is Strange and/or Gone Home, this is the next game you can play.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												I liked searching for clues and reading the characters' memories. I enjoyed the pace; it's slow and allows opportunity for introspection. But the choices that I had to make on behalf of the characters were heartwrenching. The scenarios were so realistic-situations that most of us will be in at one point or another. I don't think I chose well during my first play through; I'll have to play again and see if the outcome will be different. Overall I really enjoyed this game. It gave me lots to think about, both within the game and how I would handle similar conflicts in my own life.

Posted: January 6
												It's an intriguing concept, but this game is really boring in its execution. It moves at a really slow pace, and takes place in the same location for far too long. Perhaps if there were more to explore and uncover, it would be more interesting. Unfortunately, it's a hunt for documents while remaining unseen and traveling back and forth through light fixtures until the end of every chapter, when you make a simple decision.The depiction of a family in a rough time and what they do to get through it is pretty emotionally interesting, but it's ultimately everyday life stuff and doesn't really hook you as much as the supernatural aspect would have you believe.

Posted: January 1
												I definitely recommend this game to anyone reading this review. If you've seen any gameplay videos yet (on the Steam Store Page, or in another review online), you probably have a good grasp of what it is like to play The Novelist. It's a simple, story-driven game in which the player tries his/her best to guide a family through daily compromises in their lives. The dad wants to work late, the mom wants some family time, and the son wants to go fly his kite. My wife and I played the full game together, and we both found each scenario to be very realistic - and sometimes extremely emotional! The choices in-game carry such weight, mostly thanks to the developer's strong writing. The characters each feel real, reacting naturally to and remembering all of your choices.The game lasts a few hours, but I would not be surprised if most players wished to play two or three times to explore different paths through the story. Overall, it's a worthwhile, moving game.

												Its OK. Not amazing though. I'd wait for a sale.

Posted: January 8
												Really enjoyed this game, some of the decisions were difficult and I ended up consulting my own family on what they would do. Definitely a game for relaxing, not fast paced at all and a lot of reading, listening and thinking is involved. Overall very enjoyable. While I could play it again, I am satisfied with my ending.

Posted: January 14
												This could have been called the work-life balance simulator, or simply the guilt simulator because it is hard to make everyone happy.It's a good game. You influence the lives of a family through choices that have consequences, and you try to get a good outcome. It's similar to some Telltales games in that aspect, but the format and mechanics are entirely different and original.It's a bit short at 2 hour completion time. There might be replay value exploring different choices, but i got the outcome i wanted and I have no desire to replay this game. I'd recommend you get it on a sale.

Posted: January 15
												It was an ejoyble way to pass a few hours. Your choices decide the fate of this family, whether he focuses on his carreer and neglects his wife and son, or not. While it is very story rich, and some of the choices are more difficult to make, it does get a bit repetitive after the first play through, as you do the same thing in every act, (find clues, dodge the people, still stuck in the little house) but there is a casual level so you can speed through the game and see the other outcomes. It would have been nice if it wasn't in the house the entire game, or at least have been a bigger area. I'd still recommend it.
